thinkers.name: Michael Levin
thinkers.context: Director of the Allen Discovery Center at Tufts University; primary author of this paper on generalizing frameworks for sentience beyond natural species.

thinkers.name: Paul Lyon
thinkers.context: Key researcher in the field of basal cognition studying primitive cognitive capacities in bacteria, slime moulds, and other non-neural systems.

thinkers.name: Giovanni Pezzulo
thinkers.context: Collaborator with Levin on applications of computational neuroscience to understanding morphological regulation and cognition.

thinkers.name: David Chalmers
thinkers.context: Philosopher referenced for work on the hard problem of consciousness and the mind-body problem.

thinkers.name: Thomas Nagel
thinkers.context: Philosopher referenced for work on consciousness and subjective experience.

thinkers.name: Calvo
thinkers.context: Researcher studying plant intelligence and sentience.

thinkers.name: Fred Keijzer
thinkers.context: Collaborator on research examining cognitive similarities and differences across diverse biological systems.

concepts.name: Consciousness
concepts.context: Central concern of the paper; capacity for subjective experience in diverse agents including conventional organisms, bioengineered entities, and artificial intelligences.

concepts.name: Sentience
concepts.context: Capacity to experience suffering and wellbeing; the paper argues for developing rigorous frameworks to identify sentience beyond familiar biological touchstones.

concepts.name: Basal Cognition
concepts.context: Field studying evolutionary origins and primitive versions of cognitive capacities in non-neural systems like bacteria, slime moulds, cells, and tissues.

concepts.name: Artificial Intelligence
concepts.context: Software or embodied agents with sophisticated performance; raises questions about sentience assessment when verbal reports and brain homology are absent.

concepts.name: Extended Mind Hypothesis
concepts.context: Theory that cognitive processes can extend beyond the brain into external tools and materials; relevant to understanding distributed cognition in cyborgs and hybrid systems.

concepts.name: Problem of Other Minds
concepts.context: Philosophical challenge of determining whether other entities possess sentience and consciousness; central to developing sentience assessment frameworks.

concepts.name: Mind-Body Problem
concepts.context: Fundamental question of why functional/structural criteria should be associated with subjective feeling; acknowledged as likely unsolvable in third-person analysis.

concepts.name: Synthetic Morphology
concepts.context: Field creating coherent, autonomous beings with radically different anatomies and control structures from natural life forms; raises novel sentience questions.

concepts.name: Cyborg
concepts.context: Integration of living tissue and smart materials creating agents with extended sensory capabilities and cognitive modulation.

concepts.name: Hybrots
concepts.context: Systems combining biological neural tissue with robotic embodiment; demonstrate proto-cognitive capacities of cells in novel configurations.

concepts.name: Gene Regulatory Networks
concepts.context: Non-neural systems capable of associative learning and memory; relevant to recognizing cognition beyond traditional neural architectures.

concepts.name: Agency
concepts.context: Property of autonomous action and intentionality; human capacity to recognize agency is well-tuned for familiar entities but poorly adapted to unconventional forms.

concepts.name: Intelligence
concepts.context: Competence and capability across diverse problem spaces (linguistic, physiological, metabolic, transcriptional, anatomical); not limited to neural substrates.

concepts.name: Nociception
concepts.context: Criterion #1 in Crump et al.'s framework; detection of harmful stimuli, foundational to assessing sentience.

concepts.name: Sensory Integration
concepts.context: Criterion #2 in Crump et al.'s framework; combining information from multiple sensory inputs.

concepts.name: Motivational Trade-Offs
concepts.context: Criterion #5 in Crump et al.'s framework; weighing conflicting drives and preferences in decision-making.

concepts.name: Analgesia Preference
concepts.context: Criterion #8 in Crump et al.'s framework; preference for pain relief indicating subjective experience of suffering.

concepts.name: Associative Learning
concepts.context: Criterion #7 in Crump et al.'s framework; ability to link stimuli or events; occurs even in gene regulatory networks.

concepts.name: Coarse-Graining
concepts.context: Process of simplifying complex continuums into discrete categories; human tendency to artificially divide humans from animals rather than recognize continuums.

concepts.name: Plasticity
concepts.context: Property of life enabling adaptation and reconfiguration; allows diverse combinations of evolved and designed materials to constitute viable selves.

concepts.name: Embodiment
concepts.context: Role of physical body in cognition; diverse possible embodiments raise questions about how consciousness depends on particular substrates.

concepts.name: Self
concepts.context: Entity capable of self-protection and autonomous action; concept that may apply to diverse biological and artificial agents beyond humans.

concepts.name: Teleonomy
concepts.context: Goal-directedness in biological systems; relevant to understanding agency and intentionality in diverse forms of life.

concepts.name: Developmental Bioelectricity
concepts.context: Electrical signaling in development; mechanism underlying multicellularity and scale-free cognition beyond traditional neural activity.

concepts.name: Scale-Free Cognition
concepts.context: Cognitive processes operating across multiple organizational levels from cells to organisms; challenges traditional neurocentric views of mind.

concepts.name: Pattern Regulation
concepts.context: Maintenance of biological patterns and forms; understood through free-energy approaches and morphogenetic principles.

concepts.name: Competency in Navigating Arbitrary Spaces
concepts.context: Invariant capability across diverse embodiments; proposed as a fundamental marker of cognition applicable to diverse agents.

concepts.name: Downward Causation
concepts.context: Influence of higher-level organization on lower-level components; relevant to understanding how organisms control morphology and regeneration.

concepts.name: Artificial Life
concepts.context: Computational simulation and creation of life-like systems; relevant to understanding cognition and agency in non-biological substrates.

frameworks.name: Crump et al.'s Eight Criteria for Sentience
frameworks.creator: Crump et al.
frameworks.context: Quantitative framework for assessing sentience including nociception, sensory integration, motivational trade-offs, analgesia, flexible self-protection, and associative learning; provides foundation for extending sentience assessment beyond familiar species.

frameworks.name: Smith & Boyd Criteria
frameworks.creator: Smith and Boyd
frameworks.context: Earlier ethical framework for assessing sentience; noted as inadequate for novel, unconventional agents that lack familiar phylogenetic or anatomical touchstones.

frameworks.name: Turing Test
frameworks.creator: Alan Turing
frameworks.context: Test for machine intelligence based on verbal behavior; criticized as insufficient criterion for assessing sentience in diverse agents including non-verbal bioengineered systems.

institutions.name: Allen Discovery Center
institutions.context: Research center at Tufts University directed by Michael Levin; focuses on intersection of developmental biology, computer science, and cognitive science.

institutions.name: Tufts University
institutions.context: University hosting the Allen Discovery Center and Michael Levin's research on bioengineering and synthetic morphology.

institutions.name: Wellbeing International
institutions.context: Organization providing open access publishing and repository for Animal Sentience journal and related research.

institutions.name: Institute of Medical Ethics
institutions.context: Institute that produced the Smith & Boyd report on ethical use of animals in biomedical research.

questions.question: What are the appropriate criteria for assessing sentience in novel, unconventional agents that lack familiar phylogenetic origins or anatomical structures?
questions.context: Central question driving the paper; necessary for developing moral frameworks as bioengineering, AI, and synthetic morphology create beings fundamentally different from natural species.

questions.question: How can we identify and evaluate the sentience of beings created through bioengineering, synthetic morphology, and AI that offer no familiar touchstones?
questions.context: Practical question about future responsibility toward chimeric organisms, hybrots, and artificial intelligences with unprecedented compositions and behaviors.

questions.question: Why should functional or structural criteria be associated with subjective feeling and consciousness?
questions.context: The hard problem of consciousness; acknowledged as likely unsolvable in third-person analysis but should not prevent progress on practical sentience assessment.

questions.name: Problem of Other Minds in Non-Biological Contexts
questions.question: How can we determine if non-biological entities like Large Language Models or bioengineered systems possess genuine sentience versus sophisticated information processing?
questions.context: Exemplified by debate over LaMDA sentience; requires moving beyond verbal reports and brain homology to develop principled assessment methods.

questions.question: How should we distinguish between genuine sentience and behavioral mimicry in AI systems and synthetic organisms?
questions.context: Challenge posed by agents that may advocate for themselves verbally or behaviorally without genuine subjective experience; undermines traditional criteria.

questions.question: What universal invariants or deep principles might underlie sentience across all possible minds and embodiments?
questions.context: Fundamental research direction; requires moving beyond frozen accidents of evolution toward identifying what is truly fundamental about sentient beings.

questions.question: Can cognition exist in non-neural biological systems such as gene regulatory networks, cells, tissues, and plants?
questions.context: Question explored through basal cognition research; if true, expands conception of sentience bearers and criteria for ethical concern.

questions.question: Is developing principled frameworks for recognizing sentience in diverse intelligences an existential requirement for humanity?
questions.context: Concluding argument that ability to recognize sentience beyond current limitations may be essential for human survival as embodiments and forms of intelligence evolve.
